014package org.jdbi.v3.core.transaction;
015
016import java.sql.SQLException;
017import java.util.ArrayDeque;
018import java.util.ArrayList;
019import java.util.Deque;
020import java.util.List;
021import java.util.function.Consumer;
022
023import org.jdbi.v3.core.Handle;
024import org.jdbi.v3.core.HandleCallback;
025import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.JdbiConfig;
026
027/**
028 * A TransactionHandler that automatically retries transactions that fail due to
029 * serialization failures, which can generally be resolved by automatically
030 * retrying the transaction.  Any HandleCallback used under this runner
031 * should be aware that it may be invoked multiple times and should be idempotent.
032 */
033public class SerializableTransactionRunner extends DelegatingTransactionHandler implements TransactionHandler {
034    /* http://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/static/errcodes-appendix.html */
035    private static final String SQLSTATE_TXN_SERIALIZATION_FAILED = "40001";
036
037    public SerializableTransactionRunner() {
038        this(LocalTransactionHandler.binding());
039    }
040
041    public SerializableTransactionRunner(TransactionHandler delegate) {
042        super(delegate);
043    }
044
045    @Override
046    @SuppressWarnings("PMD.PreserveStackTrace")
047    public <R, X extends Exception> R inTransaction(Handle handle,
048                                                    HandleCallback<R, X> callback) throws X {
049        final Configuration config = handle.getConfig(Configuration.class);
050        int attempts = 1 + config.maxRetries;
051
052        Deque<X> failures = new ArrayDeque<>();
053        while (true) {
054            try {
055                R result = getDelegate().inTransaction(handle, callback);
056                config.onSuccess.accept(new ArrayList<>(failures));
057                return result;
058            } catch (Exception last) {
059                X x = (X) last;
060
061                // throw immediately if the exception is unexpected
062                if (!isSqlState(config.serializationFailureSqlState, x)) {
063                    throw last;
064                }
065
066                failures.addLast(x);
067                config.onFailure.accept(new ArrayList<>(failures));
068
069                // no more attempts left? Throw ALL the exceptions! \o/
070                attempts -= 1;
071                if (attempts <= 0) {
072                    X toThrow = failures.removeLast();
073                    while (!failures.isEmpty()) {
074                        toThrow.addSuppressed(failures.removeLast());
075                    }
076                    throw toThrow;
077                }
078            }
079        }
080    }
081
082    @Override
083    public <R, X extends Exception> R inTransaction(Handle handle,
084                                                    TransactionIsolationLevel level,
085                                                    HandleCallback<R, X> callback) throws X {
086        final TransactionIsolationLevel initial = handle.getTransactionIsolationLevel();
087        try {
088            handle.setTransactionIsolation(level);
089            return inTransaction(handle, callback);
090        } finally {
091            handle.setTransactionIsolation(initial);
092        }
093    }
094
095    @Override
096    public TransactionHandler specialize(Handle handle) throws SQLException {
097        return new SerializableTransactionRunner(getDelegate().specialize(handle));
098    }
099
100    /**
101     * Checks whether a given exception is in a specific SQL state.
102     *
103     * @param expectedSqlState The expected SQL state.
104     * @param throwable The Throwable to test.
105     * @return True if Throwable or one of its causes is an SQLException whose SQLState begins with the given state.
106     */
107    protected boolean isSqlState(String expectedSqlState, Throwable throwable) {
108        Throwable t = throwable;
109
110        do {
111            if (t instanceof SQLException) {
112                String sqlState = ((SQLException) t).getSQLState();
113
114                if (sqlState != null && sqlState.startsWith(expectedSqlState)) {
115                    return true;
116                }
117            }
118        } while ((t = t.getCause()) != null);
119
120        return false;
121    }
122
123    /**
124     * Configuration for serializable transaction runner.
125     */
126    public static class Configuration implements JdbiConfig<Configuration> {
127        private static final int DEFAULT_MAX_RETRIES = 5;
128
129        @SuppressWarnings("UnnecessaryLambda") // constant for readablity
130        private static final Consumer<List<Exception>> NOP = list -> {};
131
132        private int maxRetries = DEFAULT_MAX_RETRIES;
133        private String serializationFailureSqlState = SQLSTATE_TXN_SERIALIZATION_FAILED;
134        private Consumer<List<Exception>> onFailure = NOP;
135        private Consumer<List<Exception>> onSuccess = NOP;
136
137        public Configuration() {}
138
139        private Configuration(Configuration that) {
140            maxRetries = that.maxRetries;
141            serializationFailureSqlState = that.serializationFailureSqlState;
142            onFailure = that.onFailure;
143            onSuccess = that.onSuccess;
144        }
145
146        /**
147         * Sets the maximum number of retry attempts before aborting.
148         *
149         * @param maxRetries The maximum number of retry attempts before aborting.
150         * @return this
151         */
152        public Configuration setMaxRetries(int maxRetries) {
153            if (maxRetries < 0) {
154                throw new IllegalArgumentException("\"" + maxRetries + " retries\" makes no sense. Set a number >= 0 (default " + DEFAULT_MAX_RETRIES + ").");
155            }
156
157            this.maxRetries = maxRetries;
158            return this;
159        }
160
161        /**
162         * Sets the SQL state to consider as a serialization failure.
163         *
164         * @param serializationFailureSqlState the SQL state to consider as a serialization failure.
165         * @return this
166         */
167        public Configuration setSerializationFailureSqlState(String serializationFailureSqlState) {
168            this.serializationFailureSqlState = serializationFailureSqlState;
169            return this;
170        }
171
172        /**
173         * Set a consumer that is called with a list of exceptions during a run. Will not be called with any exceptions that are not the configured
174         * serialization failure. These will simply be thrown, aborting the operation. Can be used e.g. for logging.
175         *
176         * @param onFailure A consumer to handle failures. Will never be called with Exceptions that have not been configured.
177         * @return this
178         */
179        public Configuration setOnFailure(Consumer<List<Exception>> onFailure) {
180            this.onFailure = onFailure;
181            return this;
182        }
183
184        /**
185         * Sets a consumer that is called after a run has completed successfully. The consumer will received any exceptions that happened during the run. Will
186         * not be called with any exceptions that are not the configured serialization failure. This can be used to e.g. log all exceptions after a successful
187         * run.
188         *
189         * @param onSuccess A consumer to handle the list of failures after the run has been completed successfully.
190         * @return this
191         */
192        public Configuration setOnSuccess(Consumer<List<Exception>> onSuccess) {
193            this.onSuccess = onSuccess;
194            return this;
195        }
196
197        @Override
198        public Configuration createCopy() {
199            return new Configuration(this);
200        }
201    }
202}
